#include <stdio.h>
#include <stdlib.h>
#include <string.h>
#include <stdbool.h>

Define dynamic arrays for li entries.

Then:

int main() {
    int n, m;
    scanf("%d %d", &n, &m);
    getchar(); // consume newline

    // Read m lines for li
    int **li = (int **)malloc(m * sizeof(int *));
    int *li_sizes = (int *)malloc(m * sizeof(int));
    bool *in_q = (bool *)calloc(n + 1, sizeof(bool)); // track elements in q
    int q_capacity = 10;
    int q_size = 0;
    int *q_elements = (int *)malloc(q_capacity * sizeof(int));

    for (int i = 0; i < m; i++) {
        char line[1000000]; // assuming line is not longer than this
        fgets(line, sizeof(line), stdin);
        char *token = strtok(line, " \n");
        int k = 0;
        int *nums = NULL;
        int count = 0;
        // first token is the count (but we ignore it)
        if (token != NULL) {
            token = strtok(NULL, " \n"); // skip first token
        }
        while (token != NULL) {
            int num = atoi(token);
            if (count == 0) {
                nums = (int *)malloc(sizeof(int));
            } else {
                nums = (int *)realloc(nums, (count + 1) * sizeof(int));
            }
            nums[count++] = num;

            // Check if num is already in q_elements
            if (!in_q[num]) {
                in_q[num] = true;
                if (q_size >= q_capacity) {
                    q_capacity *= 2;
                    q_elements = (int *)realloc(q_elements, q_capacity * sizeof(int));
                }
                q_elements[q_size++] = num;
            }

            token = strtok(NULL, " \n");
        }
        li[i] = nums;
        li_sizes[i] = count;
    }

    // Read p array
    int *p = (int *)malloc(m * sizeof(int));
    for (int i = 0; i < m; i++) {
        scanf("%d", &p[i]);
    }

    // Create index_of array
    int *index_of = (int *)malloc((n + 1) * sizeof(int));
    for (int i = 0; i <= n; i++) {
        index_of[i] = -1;
    }
    for (int i = 0; i < q_size; i++) {
        index_of[q_elements[i]] = i;
    }

    // Precompute masks for each u_i
    unsigned int *masks = (unsigned int *)malloc(m * sizeof(unsigned int));
    for (int i = 0; i < m; i++) {
        unsigned int mask = 0;
        for (int j = 0; j < li_sizes[i]; j++) {
            int element = li[i][j];
            int idx = index_of[element];
            mask |= (1U << idx);
        }
        masks[i] = mask;
    }

    // Calculate v_size
    int v_size = n - q_size;

    // Iterate through all subsets
    long long ans = 0;
    int total_subsets = (1 << q_size);
    for (int s_mask = 0; s_mask < total_subsets; s_mask++) {
        int valid = 1;
        for (int i = 0; i < m; i++) {
            unsigned int and_mask = s_mask & masks[i];
            int parity = __builtin_popcount(and_mask) % 2;
            if (parity != p[i]) {
                valid = 0;
                break;
            }
        }
        if (valid) {
            ans += (1LL << v_size);
        }
    }

    printf("%lld\n", ans);

    // Free all allocated memory
    for (int i = 0; i < m; i++) {
        free(li[i]);
    }
    free(li);
    free(li_sizes);
    free(in_q);
    free(q_elements);
    free(p);
    free(index_of);
    free(masks);

    return 0;
}

But after the li lines, the code uses fgets to read the li lines, but after that, when reading p, the code uses scanf. But after fgets, the input buffer may have remaining characters. But if the li lines were read with fgets, the newline after the li lines is already consumed. So the p array is read correctly.

But suppose after reading the m lines for li, the code calls fgets to read the p line. But in the code above, after the for loop for reading li lines, the code reads p using scanf("%d") in a loop. That's correct because each call to scanf will skip whitespace and read the next integer. Another possible issue is the use of __builtin_popcount. This is a GCC-specific function. To make the code more portable, we can compute the parity manually. For example:

int parity = 0;
unsigned int x = and_mask;
while (x) {
    parity ^= 1;
    x &= x - 1; // clear the least significant set bit
}

This loop counts the number of set bits modulo 2. So for each bit set, parity flips. So if the count is even, parity is 0; if odd, parity is 1.

So replacing __builtin_popcount(and_mask) % 2 with this loop would make the code more portable.

        break;
    }
}

This would be better for portability.
